comments.commentBody: I am quite confident that the republicans will do as little as possible. When that happens that will prove that they have no honor and are merely a bunch of cowards relying on trump to keep them in power and spoon feed them whatever gravy can be arranged. They are basically even more disgusting than even trump.
hey I never  said that I was surprised. They are republicans after all.!
I never had sex with that girl. I never told anyone to lie. Never. Not once.

These are admirable efforts by some states.  The challenge for workers and for employees who operate in multiple states is that we will end up with a patchwork of regulations and plans...which only creates difficulties for all. A standard national approach which accomplishes this would be best.

Beyond the fact that the Russian deliberately interfered in the election to the disadvantage of Clinton there are two things which should draw concern. First was the elimination of an anti Russian position in the Republican platform. Who supported the removal? And who in the Trump campaign organization had contacts with the Russians around that time. Second, after it was clear that the Russians had interfered in the election, who in the Trump organization had contacts with the Russians, and why is it when sanctions were placed on the Russians for their action, the Russians did not retaliate in the usual manner? Both of these matters suggest the possibility of a quid pro quo.
Entering extremely dangerous turfs - Civil War

Who? Follow the money: Paul Manafort, Carter Page, Roger Stone, Michael Flynn, Jefferson Sessions, TIllerson, Wilbur Ross all have or had Russian connections. U.S. intelligence agencies “intercepted communications and financial transactions” between Russian officials and Trump allies; specifically Roger Stone, Paul Manafort, and Carter Page. Worth a look:
http://mediamatters.org/blog/2017/01/19/new-york-times-trump-ally-roger-...

As a Le Carre fan, I've been following all this with great fascination. It was very frustrating for those long weeks when everyone seemed to have forgotten about the Russians entirely, and I wanted to call Congress and yell "What are they up to? Didn't you see 'The Manchurian Candidate'?" Now CNN and MSNBC are my favorite channels. But how about those Russians who recently died of "heart attacks"--one of them in the embassy on Election Day? I'm waiting for my conspiracy theory to work itself out.
Didn't one of those Russians commit suicide? I heard it was two shots to the back of the head.
Russians have amazingly poor diets. All that vodka and fatty foods. No wonder people die of "heart attacks" all the time. /sarc.
If they just resign, don't pursue them vindictively.

I'm from South Carolina, and we'd call Sessions a Good Ol' Boy--easy-going and chatty and amiable. My dad was a Good Ol' Boy and did very well as a traveling office-supplies salesman with his own business. I'm glad he wasn't into politics, but even if he had been, he wouldn't have gone Sessions' route--he was remarkably tolerant of everyone, regardless of race or religion or gender.

This just in: The Donald declares that he prefers the Russian Mafia to the American one.  Seriously, is this how we make America great again?  By cooperating with the Russians to steal (okay, "influence") our elections and by hailing a despot like Putin as a role model for the future leaders of our nation?  Are those tax cuts for the affluent so very important to educated conservatives that they're willing to let our kitty-grabber-in-chief slime their own country as part of the bargain?
I'm just a poor boy trying to make it in a rock-n-roll band and I'd be delighted if you pass on those tax savings to me. Thanks bro
As long as the GOP gets its tax cuts, Dear Leader can do almost anything.  No tax cuts?  They'd turn on him tomorrow, especially as their Manchurian Candidate, Pence is in place.

If we were to scrutinize Sessions' actions for racist intent or outcome the only thing that might get other Republicans hot and bothered would be his coming out in favor of lynching (and not just the high-tech variety).  Anything less offensive would be met with a collective shrug.

Concerned as I am with the stench coming from the contacts of trump et al with the Russians (as I commented earlier) I think it's important to keep a very wary eye on other doings of the administration, of which only the threat to the ACA is getting significant press.

I almost think trump welcomes the Russia scandal as a distraction that he can survive. All the while that he makes common cause with his autocratic role model Putin, he prepares to push his authoritarian and damaging agenda through executive order or Congressional action. He's already trashing the environment and action that would moderate climate change (maybe he'll change once a rising and more turbulent ocean begins to encroach on Mar a Lago).

Granted that trump's base is all for any and every action against immigrants, but that doesn't mean the rest of us should forget about it. Some grave injustices are about to be done in the shape of increased detention which will include the enforced separation of children from their parents.

No, I think Trump is deeply concerned about a Congressional investigation into his Russian affairs, but the Republicans are willing to tell him they won't investigate right up until he signs all the legislation (and scotus wins) they think they can get away with. Then they better move quickly to take him down or they will appear to have just as much Russian intrigue as he does - which they may.
No way he was unaware.  This is Donald Trump: he wouldn't let one of his untermenschen phone their own mother without his knowledge and consent.

We all know the Russian National Committee had a great Cleveland convention, a terrific Kremlin campaign strategy, and a brilliantly timed Molotov-Comey Oct 28 cocktail bomb to burn down the Presidential Election.

It all was a great success for Moscow, well deserving of the finest FSB vodka and a hearty 'nasdrovia' !

In the spirit of Senator Mitch McConnell suppressing Senator Warren's speech while she was mentioning that Jim Crow Sessions was not a great candidate for Attorney General, the press really just needs to sit down and shut up and accept the Russian-Republican results of the American election.

Jeff Sessions - who is named after both Confederate President Jefferson Davis and a prominent general of the Confederate States Army, P.G.T. Beauregard - never really cared too much for the United States of America, quietly preferring the comforts of Caucasian tyranny and the suffocating religious oppression of Sweet Home Alabama over modern America.

So what if Trump's most loyal campaign advisers and the Attorney General were consorting with an American enemy while they were staging a major attack on America's elections.

So what if the Attorney General 'can't remember' much of anything and perjured himself in front of Congress.

Isn't that what any good Confederate soldier would do when trying to overthrow the United States of America ?

Isn't Sessions' loyalty to the Grand Oligarchic Party ?

What's so wrong with Making Moscow Great Again ?

Trump Tyranny Is Terrific !

@ Socrates

Nasdrovia!!!

So we think that Sessions, from Alabama is a good role model? Is Alabama a well run state that thrives with a reputation of fairness and justice for all? I think not, and poor Alabama along with Mississippi are usually in the bottom two rungs in the USA. What did Sessions accomplish in his home state? He is unqualified and needs to be removed from this important position asap.

@socrates may I add, so what if the president of divided states of America brags how smart he is that he doesn't pay his taxes?

Only stupid people pay taxes.

This is like Nixon all over again. If the president does it it is NOT illegal.

It appears that most state-run IRAs would offer participants a limited pool of investments, which the state might have selected because they are low cost index funds, for example. California's law requires the board setting up the program to 'minimize participant fees'. Maryland's program caps fees at 0.5%.

Many small employers offer employees 401(k) investment options with high fees. While such programs are almost certainly less costly to the employer, high fees do not serve the employees, who find their savings trapped in costly funds that perform no better than cheaper alternatives to which they do not have access. I've been there.

Perhaps the Congressmen's opposition is based in fear that state-run IRAs would offer high-fee funds, but I doubt it. More likely, their opposition is just another attempt to transfer money from the pockets of future retirees to the pockets of Wall Street, just like the Trump administration's proposal to revoke the fiduciary rule for advisors of retirement funds.

carrobin, I'm a son of the South myself, at least half of me. I meant no offense.  Sessions is a good actor as much as anything. If he had really learned the right inner qualities from his mama, he wouldn't be lying and stealing- like his boss.
If his boss can get away with one lie per spoken sentence why shouldn't a mere appointee get a pass on a fib from time to time?  Heck, for these guys "denial" is just dat river in Egypt.

Sessions has now decided to "amend" his January testimony ......but he won't appear before the committee, he will do it in writing. This is a man who lacks intestinal fortitude.....he needs to be forced to come before the committee and answer a series of questions that the people of this country needs answers to.
That choice alone proves he does not want to answer under oath,so he should be forced out!
hey I never  said that I was surprised. They are republicans after all.!
Good people also don't serve in Congress...
Is 8 a Natick square or do you think that's fair for a Saturday? It's two foreign titles crossed with each other.

Re: Natick

http://rexwordpuzzle.blogspot.com/2008/07/sunday-jul-6-2008-brendan-emme...
I remember the NATICK puzzle well, because I actually knew NC WYETH.  I have no idea what the initials stand for!

Thank you, Barry. That was wonderful. Now I'll never forget it but I'll also understand how it came about. Yay, Rex Parker, for devising such a rule.

I have to wonder if I had any trouble with that puzzle from 2008. I would have known NC Wyeth and probably would have come up with Natick since I know the town. In fact, it was knowing it as an actual place that had confused me with its frequent use on this blog.

Kiki, I looked up the N&C and it stands for Newell Convers; no wonder he used the initials!

The civilian government is more or less in the hands of Steve Bannon, Jeff Sessions, and his Alabama friends.  I think we're going to see a second Redemption, in the sense of the southern white takeover of the South after Reconstruction.

stu:

That contempt on your part of Republicans simply stamps you as a bystander and not part of any solution at all.

Trump has no hotels in Cleveland or anywhere else in Ohio.  Nor in Michigan, Pennsylvania, Wisconsin, West Virginia or any other state that's been hard hit by the forces of globalization.  Nor has he announced any intention to build anything in any one of those states.  So much for his personal contribution towards bringing jobs back to the Rust Belt.

It's an abomination that our nation's chief Justice official would offer such a lie to Congress. (And it's also unfathomable why he did it.) These people are so arrogant that they think they can keep getting away with all the things they may do regularly even though they have been caught out at it. Even the most jaded among us must find it astonishing.

Every day something new. Outrage fatigue is a very real, and frightening, possibility.

Yes indeed. It is all so outrageous and farcical, and done so openly and with such straight faces.
How did we, our society, our country, get to this point?
They think they can get away with this things because so far they are.  I am frightened, too, Susan.  What should we do?

They absolutely can get away with it as long as people do not bother to get out and vote. This is all about elections- and who comes out to vote and who doesn't. The electoral college is one thing- but the Dems also lost Congress and most races on the state level- which is why we have such rampant corruption at every level.
No offense taken--Good Ol' Boys come in many forms, some not so good.

It might interest Gov. Walker to learn that members of public sector unions (like members of unions covering private industry) are also tax payers.  Why shouldn't they, too, have a right to determine how their taxes are used?  And why shouldn't they, too, have the right to collective bargaining, to go out on strike, to decent health care, etc., etc.?

Unlike private sector Unions, public sector Unions have enormous political power and are negotiating with an elected official with budget and taxing power. Private sector Unions have a stake in the company making a profit. Public sector Unions are negotiating with public officials with taxing and budget power.

Public sector Unions negotiating with politicians is a clear conflict of interest for both sides.

They have the right to vote like everyone else. That's called taxation with representation.
Because Corporations are people, people with more free speech, aka CASH, than real people.
LOCK THEM UP.  All of them.  Traitors, or liars, or thieves, or all of the above.
I mean of course:  LOCK THEM (the Republicans) UP.
What does the above post mean? It seems like a drunken rant. Why does this guy get the green check mark of "verified"?

"LOCK THEM UP. All of them. Traitors, or liars, or thieves, or all of the above."

Well, expose them first. Tax returns, Cayman accounts, sweetheart deals, emails--all officials, elected or appointed, must submit to scrutiny. Dimes to doughnuts, there'll be a veritable swarm of roaches scurrying for cover. Expose them, lay out the roach hotels, stomp on them. Take 'em to court, listen to 'em scream, RAID! Shine the light of day on government at every level.
